author: @arenashawn772
text: t-SNE in concept is a little dense to me so I am watching this video multiple times to think about the nitty gritty of itâ€¦ I have three perhaps very naive questions so far: 1) with really high dimensional feature space for some data, how do t-SNE algorithms decide how many dimensions to use for the simplified data? In PCA it can be specified by inspecting the variance of data in each of the components to decide that new featureâ€™s â€œcontributionâ€ in grouping/separating the datapoints, is there a similar measure that is used to decide how many dimensions are used in t-SNE? 2) Why is it only used as a visualization technique and not a true dimension-reduction method for data pre-processing in machine learning pipelines? 3) is it possible that the data do not converge in low dimensional space (i.e., you just could not move the second matrix so that it is similar enough to the first one)?  I dug out the original 2008 paper from SkLearn citation and  as usual was amazed by how you explained the fairly abstract idea in section 2 of the paper in a mere 20-minute long unhurried video, down to the analogy of the repelling and attraction of mapped data in the low dimensional space (the original paper interpreted the gradient decent method used to locate the low dimensional mapping of points as â€œsprings between every point and all other pointsâ€)  â€” no important detail is lost in your video yet they are organized in such a way that they follow a clear logic and do not overwhelm. That is mastery of the art of elucidation â¤   Thanks as always for digesting these complicated items for the benefit of the students and present them in simplified yet informative ways, as always!

author: @karannchew2534
text: Notes for my future revision.  STEP 1)  CREATE SIMILARITY MATRIX  For each data point, get a Similarity Score vs every other data point  -> Similarity Matrix.  Similarity Score = Distances between points converted/related to Probabilities -> pdf of points on pdf curve = Unscaled Similarities  -> Scaled Similarities  = Similarities of data are normalised regardless of spread (variation)  STEP 2)  CREATE NEW "PICTURES" ON A NEW (REDUCED) DIMENSION  For each and all data points, position data against other such that the new similarities scores (i.e. the probability score) follow the original similarities score.  Objective: Find the new values for each data points (in the new dimensions) such that the difference between the resulting new probability distribution and the original probability distribution is minimised.  The origin original distribution is (assumed?) Normal. But the new probability distribution is based on t-distribution, so that the new distances between the data (in the new dimensions) is exaggerated at the edges -> the new distribution spread the data clusters wider. This helps to show the distinct groups of data.

author: @JamesSCavenaugh
text: At 9:15 or so you say that it doesn't really make sense for a point to be similar to itself, so t-SNE defines this as 0.  Huh?  It makes perfect sense to say that a point is 100% similar to itself.  To convert an arbitrary (Euclidean, Manhattan, whatever) distance to a similarity, where the distance d is 0 <= d < +Inf and the similarity s is 0 < s <= 1, the formula is s = 1/(d + 1).  So a distance that is 0 units from itself is 100% similar to itself.   Also, your explanation for why a t-distribution is used is to prevent the clusters from clumping up together.  Wouldn't any unimodal univariate distribution work?  What's special about t instead of Gaussian, Laplace, ...?

author: @RezaRob3
text: Ok.  Now I've watched the video to the end (see my other comment)!  My question is...  Why do you say you've projected the points randomly onto the line and you want to calculate similarity scores again?  Why projected "randomly?" Wasn't the whole point of calculating similarity scores in the first place that they could be used for adjusting/clustering the points on the line?  Why calculate similarity scores _again_?  Presumably you want similarity scores calculated in the original high dimensional space, isn't that right?

author: @RezaRob3
text: I'm writing this comment while having watched only half way into this video, which is pretty unusual for me!    It is so clearly explained!  I once glanced at the t-SNE paper and didn't understand it.  If this is what it does then this is how things like this should be explained!    Really, we need people explaining science like this!  It's possible to read scientific papers, but what they fail to do is properly communicate the core idea to the reader so that the reader quickly grasps the big picture and the intent of the mathematical details without getting lost in the details.    Frequently, even a missing definition can make reading papers much harder for non experts.
